'''Protestantism''' is one of the [[Christianity#Major_groupings_within_Christianity|three major divisions]] ([[Catholic Church|Catholicism]], [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]], and Protestantism) within [[Christianity]]. It is a movement that began in northern Europe in the early 16th century as a reaction against medieval Roman Catholic doctrines and practices.<ref name="EB">"''Protestantism''." ''EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica.'' 2010. EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica Online. 15 Nov. 2010 <[http://0-www.britannica.com.umhblib.umhb.edu/EBchecked/topic/479892/Protestantism http://www.britannica.com/topic/479892/Protestantism]>.</ref>
The doctrines of the various Protestant [[Protestantism by country|denominations]] and [[non-denominational Christianity|non-denominations]] vary, but most non-denominational doctrines include [[justification (theology)|justification]] by grace through faith and not through works, known as [[Sola Fide]], the [[priesthood of all believers]], and the [[Bible]] as the ultimate authority in matters of faith and order, known as [[Sola Scriptura]], which is [[Latin]] for 'by scripture alone'.
The doctrines of the various Protestant [[Protestantism by country|denominations]] and [[non-denominational Christianity|non-denominations]] vary, but most non-denominational doctrines include [[justification (theology)|justification]] by grace through faith and not through works, known as [[Sola Fide]], the [[priesthood of all believers]], and the [[Bible]] as the ultimate authority in matters of faith and order, known as [[Sola Scriptura]], which is [[Latin]] for 'by scripture alone'.
